pain_points_original.title: Strict Govt Security & Data Sovereignty
pain_points_original.description: As the government's central legal provider, AGS must adhere to stringent, non-negotiable security protocols, including IRAP PROTECTED certification and Australian data sovereignty (NFR-SEC01, NFR-SEC04). Failure to protect sensitive government legal data poses a critical national security and reputational risk.

pain_points_original.title: AI Explainability and Ethical Risk
pain_points_original.description: Adopting AI introduces significant risk if its outputs are a "black box." AGS requires any AI solution to be transparent and explainable (NFR-REG10) to maintain legal defensibility, professional responsibility, and client trust. Opaque AI decisions could lead to flawed legal advice and reputational damage.

pain_points_original.title: Inefficient Manual Legal Workflows
pain_points_original.description: AGS faces significant productivity drains from high-volume, manual tasks across its ~570 lawyers, such as document summarisation, drafting, and discovery review. This inefficiency hampers service delivery speed and diverts skilled professionals from high-value strategic work, impacting overall output.

pain_points_original.title: Lack of Integration with Core Legal Systems
pain_points_original.description: A new AI tool must seamlessly integrate with AGS's core systems, including iManage Cloud and Elite 3E, to avoid creating data silos and inefficient workflows (Annex A, 4.5). A standalone solution would hinder user adoption and fail to leverage existing information, undermining the entire productivity goal.

pain_points_original.title: Need for Advanced 'Agentic AI' Capabilities
pain_points_original.description: AGS seeks to future-proof its legal tech stack, explicitly looking beyond standard GenAI to 'agentic AI systems' capable of autonomous, multi-step task execution (Annex A, 2.5). The strategic pain is investing in a basic tool that quickly becomes obsolete and fails to deliver transformative automation.

merge_decisions.kept: Lack of Integration with Core Legal Systems
